title: Salesforce | SMTS | Hyderabad | Jan 2025 [offer]
summary:
Position: SMTS
YOE: 5+

I got a referral for an opening back in Oct and was invited for the Hackerrank OA.

Round 1: Hacker rank OA (Nov 5)
Honestly I don
content:
Position: SMTS
YOE: 5+

I got a referral for an opening back in Oct and was invited for the Hackerrank OA.

**Round 1: Hacker rank OA (Nov 5)**
Honestly I don't remember the questions since I took it more than 2 months back. But both problems were of medium-hard difficulty. I solved both of them with all the test cases passing.

I got a call from the recruiter same day after the OA, asking about my work experience, current TC and expected TC. She mentioned that she will forward my profile to the HM and get back in couple of days. She never got back and I tried reaching out to her as well after a week but to no avail. Probably the opening got filled.
On 20th Nov, I got an email from a different recruiter about a hiring drive on Nov 29 (Fri) for a different opening and I agreed to participate. Probably I was added in their candidate pool or something once I cleared the OA and they might invite candidates from the pool for interviews much later as well.

**Round 2: Coding (Nov 29)**
The interviewer invited me on Hackerrank and there were 2 questions to be solved. We would then run the solutions against all the available testcases on Hackerrank.
```
First question: There are 3 kinds of queries on a stream of numbers:
(1, X) - Add X in your list of numbers
(2, X) - Add X to all the existing numbers
(3)    - Print the min number so far and remove it from the list

For e.g.
(1, 3) - current list = [3]
(1, 5) - current list = [3, 5]
(2, 10) - add 10 to all the existing numbers, list becomes [13, 15]
(1, 12) - current list = [12, 13, 15]
(3)  - print the minimum number and remove it from the list: 12

Second question: A variation of coin change problem
```

I was able to solve both the problems and got all test cases passing.

**Round 3: Coding (Nov 29)**
``` 
Given a large number as string (size upto 10^5). Find count of subsequences which are divisible by 4. 
Since the count could be a large number, return the count module 10^9 + 7.
```
I was expected to write the code on an editor. I was stuck initially for a very long time and started feeling frustrated too. but the interviewer was very helpful. The hint around what makes a number divisible by 4 really helped me and I was able to come up with a solution and code it. We ran the code for few test cases and there were couple of bugs in my code but we debugged it together and got a fully working code. Definitely not my best round but was able to cope and get over the line somehow.

**Round 4: System Design (Nov 29)**
1. Discussion on how to tackle the celebrity problem on Twitter (or any social media tbf)
2. Discussion on incremental, blue-green rollout/deployment strategy and how we can leverage it to gracefully rollout few features in a mobile app.

I had read about the celebrity problem and hence was able to talk around it and discuss feasible solutions. For #2, I guess my work experience helped me since we practice a lot of rollout/deployment strategies at my current workplace. This round went well overall.

**Round 5: Hiring Manager (Nov 29)**
Standard behavioral questions and discussion around his team and their work. Typical HM round.

On Dec 4, the recruiter asked me for a discussion with the LMTS (lead) of the team I was interviewing for. They named it the `fitment round`. It was a decent discussion I feel around my past work, my areas of interest and why I am looking for a change.

For more than a week there was no update and I was not very hopeful about making it. I tried reaching out to the recruiter but couldn't get to him. I got a call from the recruiter on Dec 13. He mentioned that 2-3 candidates cleared the interviews and they went ahead with the best candidate (which obviously wasn't me :). He offered me a different opening as well and in case I was interested, he would connect me directly to the HM of that other opening. But that role (and its JD) didn't excite me so I politely declined. Obviously at this point I considered the salesforce chapter closed.

To my surprise, the recruiter reached out again on Dec 30 and mentioned that there has been one more opening in the same team I interviewed for and they would like to extend me an offer :). The offer negotiation process took couple of weeks and I finally got my offer letter rolled this week. Quite a long process but all is well that ends well.

**My main learning from this was that very few things in this whole process are in your control. You can give your best in the interviews (even clear them) and you might not still get an offer. So just do your part and leave the rest to destiny :)**

**Compensation details:** https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/6297434/Salesforce-or-SMTS-or-Offer

I had read a lot of interview experiences during my preparation so this is me giving back to the awesome leetcode community. Thanks.

title: Walmart | Software Engineer 3 | Bengaluru | Offer
summary:
Education: B.Tech in Computer Science from an old NIT
Work Experience: SDE 2 at an investment bank (2.5 years of experience at the time of the interview)

I
content:
**Education**: B.Tech in Computer Science from an old NIT
**Work Experience**: SDE 2 at an investment bank (2.5 years of experience at the time of the interview)

I applied to Walmart through a referral, and after my resume was shortlisted, a recruiter reached out to me five days from the date of applying. The first round was then scheduled for the very next day.

**Round 1 (DSA and Java):**
There were two DSA questions in this round. One was https://leetcode.com/problems/task-scheduler-ii/description/ and the other was to implement pow(a, b) using Binary Exponentiation.

After that, there were questions on Java covering topics like boxing, ORM, Java Streams (finding the sum of squares of even numbers), Runnable and Callable interfaces, and thread states and a couple more questions on Concurrency and multi threading related to ExecutorService and CompletableFuture.

There were also a few questions based on my resume, including Reactive Programming and backpressure, along with some basic discussion on Kubernetes.

**Round 2 (LLD):**
The problem statement was to design an interface for submitting and managing workflows that can run tasks either sequentially or in parallel, with a provision for passing data between workflows. There was an in-depth discussion on the class diagram and design patterns, followed by coding a few interfaces, classes, and key methods.

This went on for about 40-45 minutes, after which the focus shifted to topics from my resume. Most of the questions from this point were on Kafka’s internals (log replication, leader election, durability, partitions, consumer groups) and its use cases.

**Round 3 (Hiring Manager):**
The discussion started with the tech stack used at my organization and an overview of the business problem we were solving. This was followed by a deep dive into a caching solution mentioned in my resume, covering general caching requirements and pseudo-code implementations for eviction policies like LRU, LFU, and FIFO. I was also asked how I would implement TTL in a cache.

There were a few follow-up questions on topics like CP subsystem, the CAP theorem, and managing a distributed cache across multiple pods using a consensus algorithm.

Towards the end, there were general and behavioral questions on handling bugs and production issues resolution, stakeholder and deadline management, and what keeps me motivated.

**Round 4 (HR):**
The discussion included usual HR questions like my strengths, a time when I dealt with a tough situation, and how I handle conflicts. After that, the HR explained the benefits and perks at Walmart and concluded by providing a verbal offer.

Overall the interviewers were understanding and interactive, and all four rounds were conducted with a gap of about two days between each.
I got the offer letter five days after receiving the verbal confirmation, which I accepted.

Offer details: https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/6492167/Walmart-or-Software-Engineer-3-or-Bengaluru

title: Google | L4 | Bengaluru | Jan 2025 | Offer
summary:
Hello LeetCode Community,


I'm happy to share my Google L4/SWE-III interview experience,timelines and few preparation strategies.


Background:
Graduat
content:
Hello LeetCode Community,


I'm happy to share my Google L4/SWE-III interview experience,timelines and few preparation strategies.


**Background:**
Graduate from a Tier 1 College
4+ years of experience in a Tier 1 Product Based Company (Non FAANG)
679 (147 Easy, 422 Medium, 110 Hard) problems solved on leetcode.
**Previous Comp** : 40L(31L Base + 12% bonus + RSU's)


**Initial Call**
I was reached out by a Google Recruiter on LinkedIn during the end of August 2024. As I was not very much confident, I asked for a month of preparation (Yes you can ask for time if you are not ready). To get started with, my recruiter has shared me some preparation material and set up my phone screening round.


**Preparation Phase**
I started doing one question a day on Leetcode starting jan 2024 as a new year resolution. I was moderately regular with this and solved about 150 problems till this point. Few on my own, few looking at solutions. This exercise really helped me warm up and definitely gave me a head start but I know this isn't gonna suffice from now. During this month I have dedicatedly solved every problem of Strivers SDE Sheet topic by topic, watched his videos. Last one week, I stooped solving new questions and just revised the questions I already did from this sheet, especially focusing on the ones that i could not do on my own the very first time.


**Phone Screening Round [30-09-2024]**
I was asked a typical sliding window based question and a couple of follow ups which were of medium complexity. I explained the appraoch to the interview, coded it, optimised it(O(2N) -> O(N)), did the dry run for 2 examples, one where the optimisation would help reduce the complexity. I was able to finish all this in less than 30 min, interviewer seemed happy and I was confident on my solution.


I did not hear back from my recruiter for about a month even after couple of follow up mails from my end. During this time, I had other interviews lined up, so i had to manage my coding preparation along with LLD and HLD. I continued doing 5-7 medium/hard problems a day during this time as well.


**Onsite Interviews:**


**Coding Round 1[13/11/2024]**


I was asked a geometry based question(LeetCode Medium, Google Tagged). I explained the approach, coded it up and then the interviewer asked me few C++ related questions. I had answered them. He asked one small follow up, coded up that as well. Interview was done in 30 mins.


**Coding Round 2[14/11/2024]**


In this round I was asked to design a class and a couple of methods for RLE. I coded them up and explained the complexity O(N). Then the interviewer asked me if i could do any better. Then I came up with a binary search approach and coded that as well. We were almost running out of time and then interviewer asked me a followup and mentioned to just explain the approach and not required to code it. I explained him as it is an extention of the Binary search solution I had written. He was happy with the approach.


**Coding Round 3[15/11/2024]**


I was asked a LeetCode Hard in this round, I have already solved a similar question earlier, so I was already familar with the optimised approach. I had explained the brute force approach to the interviewer first and then moved on to explaining the optimal solution. He asked me to code the optimal approach. Coded it up and did the dry run. He then asked me my first follow up - create some test cases for this method, I have come up with some happy scenarios and some edge cases as well. Then my second follow up was on scaling this method I had created for a very large use case. This is something that i was not expecting and was not prepared for. I came up with few solutions but interviewer was not very happy with them and then later explained me what he was expecting. Over all, this round went okay, but not as good as the other 2.


**Googlyness [18/11/2024]**


I had a weekend to prepare for this round. Went through some youtube videos. Went through some leetcode posts. I prepared for few questions like, what is the most critical project I worked on, challenging aspects of it and put them in STAR format. This round was taken by one of the managers. He asked me some standard questions and noted down my answers. Few of them had followups too. All in all, it went good.


My recruiter did not reach out to me for a week after this. I had couple of other offers so I emailed to my recruiter to let me know the verdict as I have to plan accordingly. Then I recieved a call saying feedback was positive and I will be moved to the team match phase.


In the coming week, I had 2 team match calls. I was interested in the second team and luckily the manager was also interested, so my recruiter moved on and created a packet for me to submit to the Hiring Committe.


After a week, I heard from my recruiter saying the Hiring Committe has put my packet on hold due to some gaps in my technical rounds. She did not mention which round or what were the gaps and neither was i told the hire signals for my rounds even after requesting. So, my recruiter arranged for 2 more additional rounds.


This time, for preparation I had solved about 50-70 recently asked Google Tagged questions in leetcode.


**Additional Round 1[18/12/2024]**


In this round I was asked a Graph based question. It could be solved with BFS or DFS, similar to Leetcode-200. I explained him both the approaches along with the time complexities. Coded up the DFS one.
Then he moved on to a different question similar to LeetCode-127 . I explained him the approach and started coding it. Then he stopped me and asked if I knew how to solve this using A*. I said I am not familar with A* algorithm, he then explained me what A* is and asked me to go through it in free time. Then he gave a follow up to the original problem , I gave him a solution with O(N^2). He asked me if i could come up with a better solution. We had talked about few other approaches and finalised on one and he asked me to just do a dry run of this and I did.


**Additional Round 2[18/12/2024]**


In this round I was asked a question realed to modified CPU Scheduling problem. I had given a brute force solution, interviewer aksed me to optimise it. It took me a while to come up with the optimal solution.Then I coded it up and did the dry run. Then we moved on to the next question which is kind of an extension to the original question. The trick was to map it to the Binary Search on Answers kind of questions. I had coded it up and explained the time complexity. Interviewer seemed happy.


As it was holiday season I did not hear back from my recruiter for a long long time. I heard back on 07-01-2025 that Hiring Committe has approved my packet for L4 but the position for the team I had earlier been matched with has been closed. So my recruiter put me in the team match phase again.


I had 2 team match rounds in the next 3 weeks and I finally I was matched with the second team(Google Ads).


**Compensation Discussion**


Two days after my team was finalised, my recruiter has called me for the compensation discussion. I was given 2 options:


**Option 1** : 35l base + 121K GSU + 15% bonus + standard google perks
**Option 2** : 37.6l base + 6l Joining Bonus +101K GSU + 15% bonus + standard google perks


I was leaning towards option 2 as I wanted more Joining Bonus. I tried to negotiate further. The next day I was given a different option:


**Option 3** : 37.6l base + 8l joining bonus + 98k GSU + 15% bonus + perks


I was good with this option and I have recevied my offer on the same day.


**Offer Date - 31-01-2025**


**Final Thoughts**
Interviewing with google is going to take a while and all we can do is nothing but be very very patient and stay focused! Happy Coding!!

title: Blinkit | SDE-2 | Sep 2024 [Offer]
summary:
Status: B.Tech (Tier-3)
Position: SDE-1 at FAANG
Experience: 3+ years


APPLICATION

Applied on Instahyre for SDE-1 role and recruiter reached out on t
content:
```
Status: B.Tech (Tier-3)
Position: SDE-1 at FAANG
Experience: 3+ years
```

**APPLICATION**

Applied on Instahyre for SDE-1 role and recruiter reached out on the same day to schedule interviews for SDE-2 role.

**ROUND-1 : DSA [60 mins]** 

The question was wrapped in a story but the gist was - Given a list of students and each student having a list of sentences, group the students who are plagiarising the content. Plagiarism is defined as the exact match of sentence between the students. For example, the four students with sentences are - A [S1, S2, S3], B [S3, S4], C[S1], D[S5]. The answer should be two groups - [A, B, C] and [D].

The question is somewhat similar to [952](https://leetcode.com/problems/largest-component-size-by-common-factor/description/) marked as LC Hard. I had solved that question earlier but wasn't able to recall the solution which I used. I coded a new approach altogether (later verified by submitting the solution on LC also, it passed all test cases). The interviewer expected to write clean working solution and test it using a few cases.

**ROUND-2 : System Design [60 mins]**

Design BookMyShow.

The expectation was to come up with appropriate HLD, API Design, Database, etc. and dive deep into the potential edge cases such as handling spurious load, prevention of double booking, quick search, etc.

**ROUND-3 : Hiring Manager [40 mins]**

Typical questions about past experience, reason to switch, etc. Offer was given during the call itself and last 10 mins were used for discussion on compensation.

Overall, the interview process was a cakewalk. Entire process was completed in 2 weeks from application to offer and the recruiter was well-spoken. 

**Compensation:** https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/5872189/Blinkit-Offer

summary: Over the past two years, I have been employed in a healthcare-based mid-sized startup in Begalore. My compensation was fixed at 16 LPA, and I accumulated a tota
content:
Over the past two years, I have been employed in a healthcare-based mid-sized startup in Begalore. My compensation was fixed at 16 LPA, and I accumulated a total of four years of experience. Recently, I have received job offers for a Senior Software Engineer position from both Siemens Healthineers and Software Engineer from STG Labs.


**Siemens Senior Software Role Level 9:**
Compensation: 22 LPA, fully fixed


**STG Labs (Simphony Technology Group Labs):**
Compensation: 25 LPA, fully fixed
Role: Software Engineer

However, they have agreed to reclassify the role to Senior Engineer on the day of joining via email.
In terms of organization, Siemens Healthineers appears to be a more reputable company, and I believe they offer a better work-life balance. However, I am concerned about the potential legacy of their technology stack. STG Labs has a more advanced technology stack, but it is not as large as Siemens. There is a compensation difference as well any inputs will be appricaited which can help me out in choosing the offer.

Schneider Electric is a multinational corporation specializing in energy management and automation solutions. Headquartered in France, Schneider Electric operates in over 100 countries and offers a wide range of products and services for various industries, including energy management, automation, and electrical distribution. With a focus on sustainability and innovation, Schneider Electric is a leading provider of solutions for efficiency and sustainability in energy management.

title: Amazon | SDE2 | Bangalore (India) | 2024 [Offer]
summary: In September an Amazon Recruiter reached out to me for SDE2 Backend role.\nExperience: 2 years 2 months at that time\nEntire process took ~2\xBD months, one rou
content:
In September an Amazon Recruiter reached out to me for SDE2 Backend role.
Experience: 2 years 2 months at that time
Entire process took ~2\xBD months, one round was rescheduled.

**OA** (3rd week of Sept 2024)
 Two questions (Medium/Hard), don't remember exact questions. All testcases were passing in both problems. Some scenarios and questions for tech decisions, and lot's of behavioral kinda questions.


**Round 1: DSA** (Last Week of Oct 2024)
1. You have given `2n + 1` numbers. Each number has his pair except one number. 
Every pair numbers are adjacent. You need to find that number who does not have his pair.

2. You are given a binary tree.
	a. You need to remove leaf node one by one and print the leaf nodes one by one. You can remove leaf node in any order.
	b. Remove a leaf node and after removing that node if it's parent became leaf node remove that node first and so on..
	c. Remove all leaf node first than remove all new leaf node and so on.

I had optimal solution in all cases. Binary search in 1; DFS code for 2a, same works for 2b as well and DFS for 2c as well but slightly different with maintaing current level and using `vector<vector<int>>` for return type.

Talked to interviewer for couple of mins and then dropped off.

**Round 2: LLD** (Last Week of Oct 2024)
Leadership principles - went amazing

I had network issue in this round, lost around 5 mins. 

I was asked to implement Amazon Locker. It's a service where users can choose a locker in building full of lockers and get their parcel delivered there. They get an OTP to access that locker. If they don't pick up their item in 7 days, item is returned and locker should be vacated. System should know which lockers are available to be booked, and if items are not picked locker should become available again. User can pick any locker from available lockers in nearby location.

I implemented almost all the required functionalities with modular code, but was unable to finish the 7 days thing. I also overcomplicated the data structures a bit, but interviewer asked me why I needed it and I was quickly able to see that we actually can do something much simpler. We had verbal discussion on the 7 day expire policy and idea was LGTM according to interviewer.

Talked about the "Just Walk Out" concept difficulties and their solutions for some time with the interviewer.

**Round 3: HLD/HM** (2nd Week of Nov 2024)
Leadership principles - went amazing

In this round, we were running out of time and got less than 35 mins for whole design portion.

Clarified Problem: You have a huge area of around 10 mil km\xB2. You have sensors in every 10 km\xB2 that send you tempareture data. Design a system to show current temprature and also supports to query past tempratures. 

I listed all the functional and non-functional requirements, did QPS and storage estimates. My whole design was based on Amazon tech. There were a LOT of cross questions like push vs pull model, why we need a particular component etc and I was not able give good answer for two. I was also not able to add a SQL database I wanted for recent data. It was discussed verbally and I also added how we can add some ML and show future predictions etc. 

Talked to interviewer for couple of mins about the team and what they do and then dropped off.

**Round 4: Bar raiser** (3rd Week of Nov 2024)
Leadership principles: went pretty good

Interviewer started with 2 sum in an unsorted array, I quickly gave 3 ideas for that, `O(n * n)`, `O(n * log(n))` and `O(n)`. He didn't ask me to implement any of those.

Followup: Assume that you already have a function `vector<vector<int>> getPairs(vector<int> arr, int target)` which returns pairs that sum upto ```target``` in array `arr`. Write a code for `vector<vector<int>> getKDimensions(int k, vector<int> arr, int target)` where you pick  `k` distinct indices from `arr` that sum upto `target`. You must use the `getPairs` function above.

This one had a short recursive code with exponential time complexity - there's no way to avoid that. I didn't exactly remember the function signature for `vector insert()`, interviewer was okay with it and code was LGTM according to interviewer. I was also not sure about time complexity as the code was slightly complicated to analyse the time complexity and I was a bit lazy to think too much - I told him what & why I thought and that I might be off by a factor of `n`. He said "okay that's fine" didn't question it further.

Talked to interviewer for ~10 mins about their old days in tech as they were very experienced.


**Compensation** (1st Week of Dec 2024)
https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/6123742/Amazon-SDE-II-India

title: Razorpay | Senior Software Engineer | Bangalore | October 2024 [Offer]
summary:
Background
 Education: B.Tech from a Tier-2 college
 Position: SDE-2 at a Banking company
 Experience: 3.5 years
 Location: Pune, India

I applied via a r
content:
**Background**
* Education: B.Tech from a Tier-2 college
* Position: SDE-2 at a Banking company
* Experience: 3.5 years
* Location: Pune, India

I applied via a referral and received a call from the recruiter two days later.

**Round 1:** Machine Coding Round
Duration: 1 hour
The task was to implement a version control system similar to Git. The system needed to support:

* Adding files for commits
* Committing files
* Creating different branches
* Rolling back to previous commits

The interviewer emphasized the rollback feature and expected a thoughtful and efficient implementation of this functionality.

**Round 2:** System Design Round
Duration: 1 hour
I was asked to design a URL shortener. The interviewer wanted me to cover the high-level design, focusing on functional requirements such as:

* Converting long URLs to short ones and vice versa
* Additionally, they expected me to address non-functional requirements like:
	* Retention policies
	* Scalability
	* Availability
* A key requirement was that the system should persist the mappings for 3-5 years, so I had to design the database with this in mind.


**Round 3:** Hiring Manager (HM) Round
Duration: 1 hour
This round was centered around my projects and work experience. The interviewer focused on:

* The technical challenges I faced and how I overcame them
* The most impactful project/work I had undertaken

We also discussed test-driven development (TDD), including my views on it, trade-offs, and how I have implemented it in real-world scenarios.

Verdict: Selected ✅

Compensation Details: https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/6229368/SDE-2-or-SSE-or-Razorpay-or-Flipkart-or-Paytm-or-FanCode

title: Zepto | Engineering Manager| Offer
summary: I recently went through the interview loop for Engineering manager with Zepto. Here\'s my experience\n\nRound 1 (HLD) - Was asked to design a stock broker. Disc
content:
I recently went through the interview loop for Engineering manager with Zepto. Here's my experience

Round 1 (HLD) - Was asked to design a stock broker. Discussion was around how to propagate the changes coming from different stock exchanges to the users who have subscribed for a stock symbol. Towards the end also discussed how to show the historical price of a stock symbol. 

Round 2 (HLD) - Was asked to design the web crawler with a variation. The user will submit a url and then you have to show all the images that can be found while crawling from the submitted url. We have to maintain the state of the job and only return the images once the job was completed(meaning all possible pages have been crawled). 

Round 3 (LLD) - Was asked to design rate limiter. Rate limiter was supposed to be created as a service and different services can specify the parameter on which rate limiting should happen and also the algorithm that needs to be applied for rate limiting. 

Round 4 (Leadership) - Discussion was about my past role. Projects I have developed, challenges faced, how will I do things differently as compared to my own startup. 

Round 5 (Hiring Manager) - This was more from the people side. How to develop a team, what operational excellence metrics to follow, how to mentor people who report to you like questions. 

Verdict - Hire

Link to the compensation - 
[Offer Details](https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/5945814/zepto-engineering-manager/2686964)

title: PayPal |SE 3 |Experience |Bengaluru
summary: 1. Online Assesment(Hackerrank) : 2 questions. 1 simple coding question specific to java OOPS concept. 2nd question did not have any language restrictions. Leet
content:
**1. Online Assesment(Hackerrank)** : 2 questions. 1 simple coding question specific to java OOPS concept. 2nd question did not have any language restrictions. Leetcode Easy-Medium Problem.
**2. Algorithms & Coding Round**: Taken by a MTS-2. asked a leetcode medium question. Asked me to further optmize it. Array based question.
**3. System Design**: Asked to design a Payment gateway. HLD. was smooth and quite friendly discussion.
**4. Role Specialization**: taken by a Manager. discussion based on projects. High level design basics. Situation based questions.
**5. BarRaiser**: In depth discussion on projects I have done. 2 easy coding questions. executed and checked output. 

**Verdict**: Cleared all rounds.

**Take away**: overall process was quite slow. After clearing online test, first interview was scheduled after almost 2 months. Main HR from was not rechable, rest HRs were from different org(Third Party, externals). Only communicated through mail. It was little difficult in terms of communication.

**Offer details**:
https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/6146518/paypal-sde-3

title: Docusign P4 [offer]
summary:
YOE: 7+
Domain: Backend

I interviewed with DocuSign on December 11th for the role of P4 Senior Engineer. I had applied through a referral to multiple positi
content:
YOE: 7+
Domain: Backend

I interviewed with DocuSign on December 11th for the role of P4 Senior Engineer. I had applied through a referral to multiple positions, and for this particular role, my resume was shortlisted. The recruiter informed me that there would be two rounds on the same day. Since I was on my notice period, I agreed to the schedule.

1st Round: Coding

The first question was https://leetcode.com/problems/house-robber-ii/description/. I provided the optimal solution, and the interviewer then extended the problem to the next version, https://leetcode.com/problems/house-robber-iii/description/. I was able to provide a working solution for this as well.

2nd Round: Design

I was asked to design a WhatsApp-like end-to-end communication app. I began by explaining the order in which I would approach the problem. My process includes:
	1.	Functional and Non-Functional Requirements:
I outline both within-scope and out-of-scope requirements, specifying that I will prioritize the in-scope requirements and address the rest if time permits.
	2.	Technical Estimates:
I discuss the expected scale, throughput, and latency requirements.
	3.	API Design and Database Schema:
For this round, we had an extensive discussion on database design, particularly the schema.
	4.	High-Level Design:
I provided an architectural overview, covering the communication flow and components involved.

The interviewers seemed satisfied with my approach and responses.

Since the feedback for the first two rounds was positive, the recruiter asked if I was willing to take another coding round later in the day. I agreed.

3rd Round: Coding

The problem for this round was https://leetcode.com/problems/spiral-matrix-iv/description/. I was able to devise the optimal solution well within the allotted time and correctly articulated the time and space complexity.

4th Round: Hiring Manager (HM)

Two days later, I was informed that the feedback from all three rounds was positive, and an HM round was scheduled.

In this round, we had a detailed discussion about my past projects. The interviewer asked several behavioral questions, followed by a technical discussion on topics such as hashing and checksums. Overall, the conversation went well, and the interviewer seemed satisfied with my answers.

Offer Details

Two days later, I received an offer. You can find the offer details here: https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/6261399/DocuSign-P4-Offer

title: Apple ICT3 | Full-Stack Engineer | Interview to Offer | Cupertino
summary: How I got shortlistedApple hires very specifically for teams and filters by candidates who have highly relevant experience. An initial resume screen is performed by the recruiters and then final shorlist is done by Managers who look for good overlap
content:
### How I got shortlisted
Apple hires very specifically for teams and filters by candidates who have highly relevant experience. An initial resume screen is performed by the recruiters and then final shorlist is done by Managers who look for good overlap in technical skills of the candidate and skills required for the role.
So it's really important to tailor the resume to the Job description for Apple.

Applied to about 10+ roles on the Apple Careers site, whose description overlapped with my experience.

---

### Recruiter Call
About a month later, a recruiter reached out regarding one of the roles. This was for a Full Stack Engineer on an internal ML platform.
Shared my experience and was able to move ahead for a Hiring Manager Round.

---

### Hiring Manager
A very candid discussion on why I chose the role, my relevant experience, why I would like to join, where I see myself, and why I chose Apple.
The conversation was very positive, and I knew I was moving to the next round


---


Technical rounds have a general similarity.
The problems were highly vague. They required me to ask the right questions to complete the problem definition and then start working on it.
They were very keen on clear communication and discussions.


### Technical Phone Screen
**Problem 1:** A vote counter
Started with this vague problem statement and narrowed it down to this -
Build a class to read millions of votes from a ballot list and perform rank-based vote counting. Had to handle batching to solve for memory usage.

**Problem 2:** Given a Binary tree of 0's and 1's where the left node is the same as the parent and the right node is opposite to the parent, determine the value of the n'th node at l'th level.
I sketched out a sample tree and then proceeded to use recursion to arrive at the solution.


### Onsite - 5 rounds

##### Coding 1
**Problem:** Given a set of characters, determine all English words that can be created.
Started the discussion on determining the inputs and outputs, the structure of the dictionary to validate against.
Built a trie with the dictionary list and tested every permutation of the characters.
Optimised it in a second approach by generating a HashSet for every anagram in the dictionary and checking against characters.


##### System Design
This was not a generic design round at all.
The interviewer was a very experienced person who had worked with Apple for over 10 years.
The round focused primarily on my experience. He picked each of my experiences and we discussed very deeply about my entire task. Why I picked it, what I did (sketched multiple diagrams for each question), how I measured performance, what I would do differently today.


##### Behavioral
This round was with a senior manager.
**Question:** Given the values of Apple, such as Deep expertise and Drive for Excellence, how have you showcased these in your career?
I started picking examples from my first job to my last job, highlighting the different lessons I had learnt - technical, cultural, and leadership.

Some key lessons I highlighted were -
- Keeping it simple (KISS).
- Don't jump to solutioning too soon.
- Respect everyone's expertise.
- Resolving conflicts.
- Motivating team members.


##### Coding 2
**Problem 1: **Given a dataset, sample n items while maintaining the original probability distribution.
Very straightforward problem, the solution was to maintain the original counts and use random to sample.


**Problem 2: **Create a React component that can display 1M records.
The problem required slicing the data and displaying only records that would fit within the scroll section.
This is a classic React interview problem.
Practice Resource : https://www.greatfrontend.com/interviews/dashboard
Had practiced questions from here which made this really easy to solve.


##### Coding 3
Discussed my expertise in React. Then the interviewer drew a basic input UI and asked me to implement it.
I showcased skills such as breaking down the UI into components, creating a higher order component, using UseEffect, UseMemo, and UseRef for functionality.

---


Mailed the recruiter for feedback as I had just cleared Amazon and had made a decision soon.
After continuous follow-up for 4 days got positive feedback.
Took another 2 days for the verbal offer and another 4 days for the written offer.

Apparently, Apple startes interviewing for a role prior to receiving approval and requires 4 levels of signatures up to the VP level to roll out the offer.

So, anyone waiting on Apple, just keep following up as they as gonna take their own time!


---


### Offer
I already had an offer from Amazon for SDE 2, and so the baseline was set.
Apple was **NOT** able to match my Amazon offer at IC3 level as I only had 4.5 YOE and didn't qualify for IC4 :(

**Base:** 175K
**Stock:** 33K / year
**Sign On: **20k
**Yearly Bonus: **7.5% = ~13k

##### 1st Year TC: 241K
**Amazon TC: 280K**
Amazon Innterview - https://leetcode.com/discuss/post/6558499/amazon-interview-expereince-l5-seattle-b-vmpa/

I still chose Apple as I didn't want to move to Seattle and deal with Amazon Culture.


---


It took me **4 months and 72 interviews** to land my first Offer after being laid off.


Just when all hopes were lost is when I landed 4 back-to-back offers and finally picked Apple!


Keep grinding people. Everything eventually works out.
Luck is as important as the hard work we put in. So, don't be discouraged if you are not getting callbacks or interviews are not converting. Its not your fault.


Stay positive!
Happy to answer any questions!

title: Paytm | Senior Software Engineer (SSE/SDE-2) | Noida | November 2024 [Offer]
summary:
Background
 Education: B.Tech from a Tier-2 college
 Current Position: SDE-2 at a banking company
 Experience: 3.5 years
 Location: Pune, India

I applied
content:
**Background**
* Education: B.Tech from a Tier-2 college
* Current Position: SDE-2 at a banking company
* Experience: 3.5 years
* Location: Pune, India

I applied via the direct application link and received a call from the recruiter within 1-2 hours.

**Hackerrank Online Assessment (OA)**
The OA consisted of two coding problems:

* A medium-level problem based on strings.
* Finding the maximum even sum subsequence in an array.

Both questions required clear understanding and efficient implementation of algorithms.

**Round 1:** Technical Round/DSA
Duration: 1 hour
This round started with a basic introduction, followed by a DSA problem:

A binary array of size n was given, and we were allowed k flips (changing a 0 to 1).
The task was to find the maximum length of consecutive 1s that can be formed.
Follow-up:
* How to print the indices of the consecutive 1s after the flips.
* Optimization strategies for both the solutions and follow-up.

The interviewer focused on problem-solving skills and optimization.

**Round 2:** Technical + Behavioral Round
Duration: 1.5 hours
This round began with a discussion about:
* My most interesting project and the challenges I faced.
* System design, including scalability, monitoring, and handling high-traffic systems.
* Resource calculation to handle load spikes efficiently.
* Soft skills like dealing with stakeholders, explaining technical constraints, and aligning with business requirements.

Verdict: Selected ✅

Compensation Details: https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/6229368/SDE-2-or-SSE-or-Razorpay-or-Flipkart-or-Paytm-or-FanCode

title: Google | L4 | Interview Experience | Offer
summary: Update:\n\nI\u2019m seeing a lot of comments asking about my compensation. I can\u2019t share it on an open platform, but if you\u2019re interested, drop your L
content:
**Update:**

I’m seeing a lot of comments asking about my compensation. I can’t share it on an open platform, but if you’re interested, drop your LinkedIn ID in the comments, and we can discuss it there.

---

Hi everyone! I recently got an **L4 Software Engineer offer at Google** and wanted to share my experience. This post might help anyone preparing for Google interviews.  


## Timeline  

- **Application**: I regularly applied on the Google Careers website and submitted another application in late October.  
- **Recruiter Outreach**: Mid-November. My profile was shortlisted, and the recruiter explained the process:  
  - **1 Screening Round** (focused on DSA)  
  - **4 Onsite Rounds**:  
    - 3 DSA interviews  
    - 1 General Non-Technical Leadership (GNL) round  
  - I was given **3 weeks** to prepare for the screening and onsites both.  

---

## Phone Screening  (Mid Dec)

- **Question**: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-question/6038441/Google-or-L4-or-Phonescreen
- **Experience**:  I initially took the wrong approach in my first follow-up, but the interviewer gave me a small hint to use my previous solution. I also made some silly coding mistakes here and there.  
- **Verdict**: Cleared! Recruiter informed me within a week.  
- **Feedback**: HR told me I need to brush up more on DSA and coding skills.  

---

## Onsite Interviews  (Early Jan)

### Disclaimer  
Due to NDA, I cannot share the exact questions from my onsite interviews. However, I’ve included **similar LeetCode questions** that closely resemble the ones I was asked. If you can solve these, you should be well-prepared for the actual interview questions.  

### Onsite 1: 
- **Question:** https://leetcode.com/problems/burst-balloons/description/
- **Experience**: I solved the problem but missed one edge case. The interviewer kindly pointed it out. I took a lot of time dry-running my code, which left less time for follow-ups. Despite that, the interviewer asked three follow-ups, which I coded up quickly and tested.  
- **Verdict**: Positive  
- **Self-Rating**: Hire / Strong Hire  

---

### Onsite 2: 
- **Question:** https://leetcode.com/problems/substring-with-concatenation-of-all-words/description/
- **Experience**: This was my best round. I coded the solution in under 10 minutes and handled two follow-ups by modifying the initial code. We wrapped up within 30 minutes. Unfortunately, the interviewer seemed uninterested, possibly multitasking, so I had to speak continuously to keep them engaged.  
- **Verdict**: Positive  
- **Self-Rating**: Strong Hire  

---

### Onsite 3: 
- **Question:** https://leetcode.com/problems/moving-average-from-data-stream/description/ 
- **Experience**: This was my worst round. I misunderstood the question and spent nearly 30 minutes pursuing the wrong approach. The interviewer re-explained the problem using better examples, and with some hints, I managed to code the solution in 10 minutes. I also solved one follow-up in the last 5 minutes.  
- **Verdict**: Positive  
- **Self-Rating**: Lean Hire  

---

### **Onsite 4: Behavioral (GNL)**  
- **Preparation**: I followed the **STAR method** (Situation, Task, Action, Result) to structure my answers. Practiced for two days using this [list of behavioral questions](https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-question/5963463/Googlyness-Frequently-Asked-Questions). Fortunately, all the questions asked were ones I had prepared for.  
- **Verdict**: Positive  
- **Self-Rating**: Hire / Strong Hire  

---

## Final Outcome  

After the interviews, the recruiter informed me that I had received **positive feedback** from all rounds. I had a team-matching call two days later and received my **offer letter** last week. 🎉  

---

## FAQs  

### What was your preparation strategy?  
- Solved **Leetcode 150**, **Google-tagged questions** from the last 1–3 months, and most Google-related questions from the past year (500+ problems in total).  
- Focused on graphs, trees, and segment trees, which were my weak areas—but ironically, they didn’t appear in the interviews! 😅  
- Took **20+ mock interviews** to become confident in the interview format.  

### Can you share the exact questions?  
No, I can’t share them due to NDA, but I’ve linked similar ones.  

### What was the location?  
Bangalore, India.  

### Were the interviewers Indian or from the US?  
Indian.  

### What were the timings?  
Between **12:00 PM and 4:00 PM**.  

---

## Key Takeaways  

1. **Clarify the problem**: If unsure, ask questions early to avoid wasting time.  
2. **Stay engaged**: If your interviewer seems distracted, talk through your thought process to involve them.  
3. **Practice follow-ups**: Google emphasizes follow-up questions. Make sure you can adapt your initial solution.  

---

I hope this post helps! Best of luck to anyone preparing for Google interviews. 🚀

title: Opinion/Help needed: Strike the compensation/Life balance + where we're heading to
summary: Not all that can be counted, counts. Not all that counts, can be counted\n\nDear LCians, here to seek some opinions. I am someone who comes from a Tier-1 colleg
content:
> Not all that can be counted, counts. Not all that counts, can be counted

Dear LCians, here to seek some opinions. I am someone who comes from a Tier-1 college(IIT) but Tier-3 city :-) 
Personally, in my early 30s, and as a young man married and marred, and father of 2 kids, I think I have already aged and chained so heavily, being tied to the constraints I hold w.r.t family commitments, peace of mind. 

We may all be getting 1cr+ package at 8-10yoe, but this is:
- largely all in BLR/Hyd. 
- remote paymasters of this range are on the fingertips, infact. e.g Coinbase, what else really pays even 75L remotely?
- all these packages are barely 60% basic, maybe 5-10% bonus, 5-0% one-offs, and good 20-30% are stocks/esops

The culture somewhere we've brought ourselves into, vis-a-vis, people who've been simply unemployable had they been to tier-3 college in a medic/accountancy etc profession, are grinding LC and making such huge amounts- such that I feel bad for myself for having gone to an old IIT. 
And further in this rat race, every finish line is the beginning of a new race. This is the life of most of us:

1. Live in BLR/Hyd, in a place that barely absorbs you. Leaving family behind, away from your happy place.
> Happy lives a man, with a few paternal acres bount ... 
2. Slog 10 hrs a day, disregarding WLB, largely to pay upto 40% taxes owing to surcharge levied on whatever 50L+ you make.
> all the barrens of a busy life
3. Don't understand the difference b/w a 32-bit and 64-bit OS, but be a LC parrot or gulp-and-blab in the interviews whatever those Didi/Bhayia taught you. 
> with everyone hunting for gold here, some sell shovels : 4-5years experienced DS/A Sys Design gurus selling and teaching you half-baked system design problems that are miles away from practicality/application.

All in all, coming from my tier-3 city background, the opinion to be sought is:
" Could you generally advise a rule of thumb- from short term/long term P.O.V, which of the following to prefer": 

A. 60-65Lpa mostly cash component, but remote-working.
B. 75-80Lpa with 60-65L cash component, but hybrid + WLB. Needing to relocate to some of the busiest cities one doesnt always see belonging to.
C. 1Cr, 1+Cr, delivering high octane, surviving PIPs- disregarding that father/mother, son/daughter, brother/sister, friend/social animal in you for being a money-minting machine that operates 12hrs a day, 6days a week!

This is an open-ended, subjective discussion, and while it is not about a specific company's compensation, it is meant to stir up something in us, maybe shape the veracity/value of the compensations that the community enlists here every now-and-then, realise its impact/value holistically, and introspect where are we all heading to.

p.s: I didnt want to be rude to tier-3, but just imagine, 
\xA7. what is making us all running after the IT? are we digging our own graves? One day, jobs will be even scarce, and with entire Indian subcontinent running after these IT jobs, how a supply/demand stance shall exploit us hard when we've all established ourselves so deep into such profession?
\xA7. to the Hiring Teams, Orgs, and "Educators", would you go by the "degrees dont matter, colleges dont matter" narrative, if you were to say, consult a doctor, consult a CA? I want jobs for everyone, but chucking such filters away are hollistically dragging even the real talent, along with someone who crams LC word-for-word, into a deep dungeon.

title: Blinkit | SDE-1 | Gurugram | Dec 2024 | Offer
summary:
Applied through Instahyre and the entire process took a week after receving a callback from Recruiter.

Round 1: DSA
Question 1:
There are n stones and some
content:
Applied through Instahyre and the entire process took a week after receving a callback from Recruiter.

**Round 1: DSA**
Question 1:
There are n stones and some of the stones have frogs on them. A frog can jump to next vacant stone i.e it can jump over some frogs if there isn't any vacant stone in between. Minimum no.of jumps needed for all the frogs to jump to the rightmost stone needed to be found. Have explained the greedy approach to favour jumping over as many frogs as possible. After a few dry runs and some discussion with the interviewer, I found out that the index of the left most frog is what we needed and this is an O(1) Solution. Interviewer was satisfied.
Question 2:
I was expected to explain how removing a node from binary search tree would work. I couldn't come up with the `left most node of right subtree` or `right most node of left subtree`  all by myself, needed some help from the interviewer.

**Round 2: System Design**
This round was with an SDE-2, I was asked to build a rider onboarding application. First 15-20 mins went for discussing the requirements and defining the scope of the problem. Then I was asked to decide between SQL and NoSQL database. I was grilled thorughly for every decision i took. Then, discussion went into internal details of Amazon Dynamo Db, types of indexes it has and how i would define tables for this usecase and defining Partition Key & Sort Key for each table. At the end, I was asked on ways to reduce latency in Http Server, had discussions on Status Code based Retries, Long & Short Polling.
This round went for 75 mins and got positive feedback from the interviewer.

**Round 3: Culture Fit**
This was more of a disclaimer thing, making sure we align with the high-paced work culture of blinkit, was given the offer in this interview itself. I didn't negotiate as the offer was more than what i expected.

Offer Details:https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/6205008/blinkit-sde-1-gurugram

title: DocuSign | P3 | Bengaluru [Offer]
summary:
YoE: 7
Position: SSE in a fintech
Date: November, 2024

Round 1 (DSA)
https://leetcode.com/problems/serialize-and-deserialize-binary-tree/description/

\
content:
YoE: 7
Position: SSE in a fintech
Date: November, 2024

**Round 1** (DSA)
https://leetcode.com/problems/serialize-and-deserialize-binary-tree/description/


**Round 2** (Design)
It was around designing a logging service. Different clients should be able to integrate this service to push and monitor logs. Focus was on high scalability, optimal DB choices, Search feature for logs etc.



**Round 3** (LLD)
This was more of a pair programming round. Working code was not expected but focus was more on modularity, extensibility and abstractions.
Problem was somewhat on these lines: There are boxes of different sizes (small, medium, large). Small box can fit within medium and medium can fit within large. 
Implement below two features:

```
insertBox(Box b1, Box b2)  -> insert box b1 into b2

printBoxes() -> print all boxes currently added in the system. printing should be done in hierarchical order.
/*
	Sample print structure with boxes large(B1, B2); medium(B3, B4); small(B5, B6)

	B1
		-B3
			-B5
			-B6
		-B4
	B2
*/
```


**Round 4** (HM)
Techno-managerial round with focus on past work experiences. OOPS, SOLID, design patterns.


**Round 5** (HM)
This was an extended HM round to understand more about past experiences, future work expectations etc.

Offer : https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/6085240/offer-evaluation-wayfair-docusign/2740062

**Thoughts**: Process was smooth and had good interactions with the interviewers. Rounds were more focused on logical thinking rather than some fixed solution.

content:
Education: B.Tech CS in Tier-2 College
Years of Experience: 2.4 years
Prior Experience: SDE 1 at Saas startup
Date of the Offer: Oct 2024
Company: Salesforce (Service cloud)
Role : Backend developer
Previous techstack : Java spring boot
Title: MTS (Member of technical staff)
Location: Bangalore (flexible according to team, no rigid rules like come to office 3 times a week)
Salary/Base: ₹32,00,000
Bonus: ₹3,20,000 (10% of base)
Stock Bonus: $50,000 for 4 years (equally vested)
Total Comp: ₹45,70,000
Previous CTC: ₹24,00,000 (₹20,00,000 Base + ₹4,00,000 ESOPs per year)
Benefits: Standard salesforce benifits 
LC/CP states : around 850 questions on LC, 500 on CF (used to do in college), knight in lc , CF max rating specialist, 4 star on CC. Haven't solved much in atcoder.
Preparation strategy: 
Algorithms : 
    Used to solve leetcode regularly in year starting and gave contests to keep my coding skills sharp. When my interviews got scheduled I just went through some standard medium/Hard problems. For most of the companies doing leetcode is enough. But please do questions in depth rathar than doing it for increasing the count of questions. Please give contests on LC. Always try to attempt harder questions than your current level. 
System design : 
     For LLD I have gone through online blogs and youTube but mainly I frame my answers according to my learnings till now. Ideally at 2+ years exp you are already aware of most of the basics of LLD so go through the basics of LLD and then apply your day to day Dev skills to frame the answer (please refer some standard questions online and then frame the answer that way). 
	 For HLD you can follow CodeKarle youTube channel, that covers all the basics of hld and he has covered all the standard questions. You can watch those and form your solutions according to that because any question can be answered using basics of hld and standard questions that are already available on youtube.

One more important note please give some mock interviews for algorithms and system design both and do not take hr round very lightly, please prepare for behavioural questions seriously before your hr/hm round. 

How Did I apply : I applied thourgh referral, one of college seniors referred me in August end.
Other companies that I interviewed with : Zepto and got a call from Goldman for associate but my joining date was already very near by that time. Got ghosted by Zepto after two rounds. 

Accepted the offer as I am getting very good hike according to my current TC(and good tag on resume) and didn't get to interview with any other company which can beat this TC. My only concern is if sf has good work or not (have read some online reviews that work is not that good here). Will add interview exp in future.

title: Google || L3 || OFFER || Questions || Timeline
summary:
I recently got an offer for Google, India (L3) and it's time to give back to the LC community.A little about me:
YOE: 1.8 Years
Current Org: Well known PBC(Not MAANG)
I've applied to Google multiple times, but each time, my application status in the
content:
I recently got an offer for Google, India (L3) and it's time to give back to the LC community.

A little about me:
- YOE: 1.8 Years
- Current Org: Well known PBC(Not MAANG)

I've applied to Google multiple times, but each time, my application status in the portal showed **Not Proceeding**. However, on November 28, I received an email from a recruiter expressing interest in my profile. After responding, I got a call from the recruiter, who explained the hiring process and sent me an invitation for a prep session. They also asked me to provide available time slots for the Technical Phone Screen (TPS). Initially, I requested about a month to prepare and suggested slots for the first week of January. However, the recruiter encouraged me to choose an earlier date due to the upcoming holiday season.  

# TPS [17/12/2024]
The interviewer introduced himself and quickly proceeded with the question.
### Question 1: 
There is an array of size n. Find the sum of all possible valid subsequences in the array.
Valid Subsequence: Continuous subarray with absolute difference of 1 between adjacent elements.
Input: [4,5,4,9,10,11,3,8]
Ans: 99
Input: [11,35]
Ans: 46

### Follow up: 
You are in a memory constrained environment, Do not have space to load the entire array in the memory. 

I began by clarifying the constraints and then explained the brute force approach, followed by the optimal solution with an example. I also outlined the expected time and space complexity of the brute force and the optimal approach. The interviewer then asked me to code the optimal solution. After coding, I dry-ran the implementation using a few edge cases and the given example. The interviewer seemed satisfied, though the dry run took some time due to calculations.  

With limited time remaining, the interviewer proceeded with a follow-up question. I explained my approach, and he appeared satisfied but did not ask me to code. Towards the end, I asked a few questions about Google's work culture, and the interview concluded.  

Within two hours, I was informed that the feedback was positive, and I was asked to share my availability for onsite rounds.

I shared my available time slots for the onsite interviews and took about a month to prepare.

# OS1 [09/01/2025]

The interviewer briefly introduced himself and asked for a quick introduction from me. He then provided a quick overview of the process and expectations before proceeding with the questions.

### Question 1:
There are piles of car parking tickets, each having the arrival time and departure time of the car. Return the number of cars in the garage at any given time. 

### Follow up: 
The question was turned into a garage system design question, with constraints like capacity of the garage, day checks and parking fee calculation

### Question 2:

You are given multiple (x,y) coordinates. For any point give the number of rectangles covering the point.
Similar Question: Count Number of Rectangles Containing Each Point - LeetCode [Difference: Rectangle didn’t have one corner in the origin]

I was able to solve the first question along with its follow-up, but I struggled with the second question. I proposed an approach, but the interviewer didn’t seem fully convinced. I tried hard to refine my solution, but despite my efforts, the interviewer simply nodded without indicating much progress. Eventually, I admitted that I couldn’t come up with a better approach. The interviewer was very kind and reassured me, saying that even if I spent the next 10 minutes finding a solution, we wouldn’t have enough time to code it. He quickly presented another question, and I took a moment to regain my composure and focus, determined to give my best effort in solving it.
### Question 3:

This question was related to logs of a telephone company. He asked me to create two functions, one for registering each log and one to find the most talkative person at any timestamp (whenever the function is invoked)

I asked for a few clarifying questions related to the format of the logs and quickly came up and coded the optimal solution and the interviewer seemed satisfied.

**Self Rating:** Lean Hire

# OS2 [10/01/2025]
The interviewer introduced himself and proceeded with the questions.

### Question 1:
Similar to: Minimum Area Rectangle - LeetCode [Replace Minimum with Maximum]
Follow Up:
The rectangles formed are not parallel to the axis.

### Question 2:
There are multiple centres which communicate with each other. There are two-way communication channels between the centres. There is a list of corrupted stations.
Given the communication channels, source and destination nodes, determine if you can reach the destination node without traversing through any of the corrupted stations.

I successfully solved both questions optimally, explained my approaches along with their time complexities, and dry-ran the solutions using edge cases and a few example test cases. The interviewer seemed satisfied with my responses.  

Towards the end, I asked about working at Google, the team he is part of, and the coding culture among employees. The interview concluded about 10 minutes early.

**Self Rating:** Strong Hire


# Reschedule:

The $3^{rd}$ coding round and the Googliness interview were originally scheduled for January 11, 2025, and January 12, 2025, respectively. However, both were rescheduled just two hours before their scheduled times due to the interviewer's unavailability.

# OS3 [23/01/2025]

The interviewer quickly introduced himself and pasted the question.
### Question 1:
Similar to: https://leetcode.com/discuss/post/1670250/google-phone-airplane-schedule-by-l55tco-bwer/

### Follow up:
Couldn't find a similar question in Leetcode. But the earlier question was modified to return all possible routes (backtracking)

I successfully solved both questions optimally, but the interviewer maintained a neutral expression and remained straight-faced throughout the interview. He was highly focused on time and space complexities, questioning every data structure I chose. I wasn’t given a predefined input format for the questions, and the interviewer asked how the time complexity would change if the input were provided in a different format or if there were alternative ways to store the inputs.

**Self Rating**: Hire

# Googliness [24/01/2025]

The interview included general leadership and situational questions, which I answered honestly—or rather, based on what felt right to me. In the end, I asked my own questions about Google's benefits and work culture.


# Feedback:
I never recieved a detailed feedback. My recruiter mentioned the feedback is positive and my profile is being routed for team-matching, 3 hours after the Googliness round.


Then began the long wait—there was no communication or team fit calls for about a month. During this time, my recruiter changed, and I received a call from my new recruiter asking if I had any experience or interest in Java. I responded affirmatively, and she mentioned that she would check with the hiring manager. The team fit call was scheduled for the very next day.

# Team Fit Call [26/02/2025]
The Hiring Manager asked about my work experience and provided an overview of the role. However, my background didn’t fully align with the role’s requirements. I explained my day-to-day responsibilities in my current job and asked more about the position. He asked if I would be open to an additional discussion with another tech lead, to which I agreed.    

By the end of the conversation, he mentioned that while he found my profile intriguing, he wasn’t entirely sure about the fit due to differences in tech stacks. The discussion lasted 45 minutes and involved a back-and-forth conversation about my reasons for transitioning to a different tech stack. Before concluding, he said, “Let me gather my thoughts and think it through. I’ll update the recruiter within two days.”

### The Offer:

- 28/02/2025: The recruiter called me with positive feedback—the team wanted to move forward, which I didn't expect! I was asked for my confirmation on proceeding, and I responded affirmatively.
- 05/03/2025: Compensation discussion.
- Recieved the offer letter, the very next day!!! 


# Preparation:
I prepared while working a full-time job but practiced extensively earlier during placements. Till date I have solved a total of 1008 Questions [Easy: 244, Med: 594, Hard: 170]. I subscribed to LeetCode Premium after receiving positive feedback in TPS and solved as many Google-tagged questions as possible, focusing more on recognizing patterns. I also thoroughly reviewed discussions in the LeetCode Discuss section.

There were many moments throughout the process when I doubted my performance and preparedness, but I never backed down. The journey is long and requires patience—stay committed and keep going!!

title: Flipkart | SDE 2 | Bangalore | November 2024 [Offer]
summary:
Background

 Education: B.Tech from a Tier-2 college
 Current Position: SDE-2 at a Banking company
 Experience: 3.5 years
 Location: Pune, India

I appli
content:
**Background**

* Education: B.Tech from a Tier-2 college
* Current Position: SDE-2 at a Banking company
* Experience: 3.5 years
* Location: Pune, India

I applied via a google form posted by a recruiter on LinkedIn and received an interview link the next morning only. It was a hiring drive apparently. 

**Round 1:** Machine Coding Round
Duration:
30 minutes for problem statement
1.5 hours for implementation
30 minutes for review and evaluation

The task was to implement a Flipkart Buy Now Pay Later application. The key requirements were:

* Users should be assigned an initial credit limit.
* While placing an order, users can choose to either:
	* Pay in cash
	* Use the Pay Later feature
* Users get 30 days to clear dues.
* Users should be blacklisted if they default on payments 3 or more times.

The problem required careful handling of edge cases like consecutive defaults and state management for user blacklisting.

**Round 2:** Problem Solving and Data Structures (PSDS)
Duration: 1 hour

I was asked two DSA questions:

* Maximum Volume of Water: Find the maximum amount of water that can be stored between vertical towers.
* Sliding Window Maximum: Print the maximum element from every k consecutive elements in an array of size n.

The focus was on optimizing the solutions and explaining the approach clearly.

**Round 3:** System Design Round
Duration: 1 hour

The problem was to design something like an Instagram Feed for Flipkart where the users could see content related to products, deals, etc. Requirements were:

* Influencers endorse brands, and users can follow brands or influencers.
* Users should see posts from the accounts they follow on their feed.
* Features like like, comment, sticker reactions, and unfollow were to be included.
* Upon unfollowing, all corresponding posts should be removed from the feed.

The interviewer delved deeply into:
* Low-Level Design (LLD)
* Database Schema for storing users, posts, followers, and interactions.

**Round 4:** Hiring Manager Round
Duration: 1 hour

This round focused on my previous work experience, specifically:

* Past projects and the challenges I faced.
* Response times, traffic management, and load balancing techniques.
* Approaches for scaling and managing resources efficiently under high traffic scenarios.

Verdict: Selected ✅

Compensation Details: https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/6229368/SDE-2-or-SSE-or-Razorpay-or-Flipkart-or-Paytm-or-FanCode

Other Interview Experiences: 

Razorpay - https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/6229095/Razorpay-or-Senior-Software-Engineer-or-Bangalore-or-October-2024-Offer

Paytm - https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/6229169/Paytm-or-Senior-Software-Engineer-(SSESDE-2)-or-Noida-or-November-2024-Offer

FanCode - https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/6229219/FanCode-(Dream-Sports-Dream11)-or-SDE-2-or-Mumbai-or-December-2024-Offer

Gojek - https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/6229239/Gojek-(GoTo)-or-Senior-Software-Engineer-or-Bangalore-or-September-2024-Reject

title: Twilio | L3 | Bengaluru [Offer]
summary:
YoE: 7
Experience: mid & large scale MNCs
Date: November, 2024

Round 1 (Coding)

Problem 1

/* 
Design a custom stack structure that supports standard
content:
YoE: 7
Experience: mid & large scale MNCs
Date: November, 2024

**Round 1** (Coding)

Problem 1
```
/* 
Design a custom stack structure that supports standard stack operations while efficiently tracking both the minimum and maximum elements at any given time. Implement the CustomMinMaxStack class with the following methods:
CustomMinMaxStack() — Initializes the stack.
void insert(int value) — Adds an element's value to the top of the stack.
void remove() — Deletes the element currently at the top.
int peek() — Retrieves the element currently at the top without removing it.
int findMin() — Fetches the smallest element in the stack.
int findMax() — Fetches the largest element in the stack.

Each method should operate with a time complexity of O(1).
 */
```

Note: Working modular code was expected by addressing all the edge cases.


Problem 2
`Design a java class that takes requests and sends them to an api endpoint. The class shouldn't send the request to the API immediately but batch them once the number of piled requests exceeds a maximum size. One constraint here is that a request can only be held for a max certain duration and once the duration exceeds the request should be sent immediately without waiting for the next batch.`

Note: Code was not expected. Discussion happened around approach and how thread & async operations would work here.



**Round 2** (Design)

Design an 'Accounts System' which will be integrated with multiple third party services.
As I understood, this was some existing system in Twilio and interviewer wanted to gauge my approach for it.
Functional Requirement
-Our system will act as a source of truth for any accountId with all relevant account details for an id stored within our system
-Third party services can make read/write requests to this system for any accountId

Note: Requirement was fairly stratight forward. Major discussions happened around API specs, DB choices, scalability, concurrency management.



**Round 3** (HM)
Standard behavioural HM rounds. Scenario based mostly and past experiences.


**Round 4** (Coding)
Similar to
https://leetcode.com/problems/minimum-knight-moves/description/


**Thoughts**: Pretty good interview process. HR was super transparent and thoughtful. Rounds were wrapped up within a week. Cumulative feedback was taken post first couple of rounds and then processed further.


**Offer**: https://leetcode.com/discuss/compensation/6091837/Twilio-or-L3-or-Offer

title: SSE@FalconX | October 2024 | Offer
summary:
YOE: 6+
Current Position: Principal Software Engineer @ Apollo 24|7
Location: Bangalore
Status: Accepted

HR Screening Round

The HR screening round was
content:
**YOE**: 6+
**Current Position**: Principal Software Engineer @ Apollo 24|7
**Location**: Bangalore
**Status**: Accepted

**HR Screening Round**

The HR screening round was very insightful, with basic questions regarding my background, experience, and interest in the role. It was very professional explaining very detail about the company how it grow and what are the values inside, later given a clear walkthrough on the actual interview and feedback process.

**Interview Overview**
I went through a total of five technical rounds, followed by one behavioral round and a team-matching round.

**DSA Rounds**
Each round consisted of two DSA questions of above-medium difficulty, similar to Leetcode-style problems. The expectation was to:
* Explain the approach with time and space complexity analysis
* Handle edge cases
* Write runnable code on a code-pair platform

**Round 1:**
1. Modified sliding window on a circular array.(Hard)
2. Modified Graph problem based on finding shortest path between any two nodes.(Medium)

**Round 2:**
1. String manipulation problem involving custom sorting.(Hard)
2. Modified Binary Search.(Medium)

✅ Feedback: Received strong hire in both rounds and proceeded to design interviews.

**Low-Level Design (LLD)**:

This round started with an algorithmic problem—merging N heaps—which was then gradually modified to handle scalability for extremely large datasets. Eventually, the discussion evolved into designing a microservice to support the solution.

Once the approach was finalized, I was asked to define the LLD for the microservice. This round was particularly interesting as it resembled real-world problem-solving in our day-to-day work.

**High-Level Design (HLD)**:
Given that FalconX acts as a trading broker for institutional clients across multiple crypto exchanges, the problem was designed around that domain.

**Problem Statement:**:
Design a trade execution engine for cryptocurrency trading, considering:

Users hold crypto balances across multiple exchanges (e.g., 2 BTC on Binance, 1 BTC on OKX, etc.).Latency varies across exchanges and is dynamically updated by downstream monitoring systems. The engine must ensure seamless trading, zero glitches, and support both cross-crypto and fiat-to-crypto trading.
The challenge was to respect these latency variations while providing the best user experience.

**Hiring Manager Round**
This round was a mix of experience-based discussion and another HLD question.

**HLD Question:**
Design a Top-K selling products/categories system for an e-commerce platform that handles high throughput (40K orders/second).

**Key areas of focus:**

* Building a low-latency architecture
* Identifying & solving hot partitioning issues

**Behavioral Round**
This round had thought-provoking behavioral questions, primarily focused on:

* My career goals
* Why FalconX?
* My motivation for switching to the financial domain
* Final Feedback & Offer
* The interview process was challenging yet insightful, thoroughly evaluating every aspect of my technical expertise.

**Final outcome:**
✅ Cleared all technical rounds
❌ The original position I applied for was closed or not suitable because of domain expertise.
🔄 My profile was forwarded to a different hiring manager
📞 Had two additional 30-minute rounds to finalize my team
🎯 Given three verticals to choose from based on my preferences
💰 Received an offer with an excellent compensation package

title: discussing compensation with HM
summary: I recently got an offer from a big tech company and there was a bit of back and forth with the recruiter about the compensation. I am experienced and have switc
content: I recently got an offer from a big tech company and there was a bit of back and forth with the recruiter about the compensation. I am experienced and have switched a few times but I never had a discussion about comp with the hiring manager. but because of the delay in acceptance the hiring manager wants to talk to me (he worded it as if I have any questions about the team). \nI don\'t know if I should discuss the compensation with the manager but I cannot push the recruiter anymore. The whole interview process will be a waste because they are not giving me a significant hike on my current.\nIn India do people go for comp discussion with hiring manager? is this frowned upon?

title: BP vs Serrala vs Chistats Offers
summary: Background: 4 YOE in software development, previously at Turtlemint, with a strong background in backend systems and cloud infrastructure.\n\nPrevious Compensat
content:
Background: 4 YOE in software development, previously at Turtlemint, with a strong background in backend systems and cloud infrastructure.

Previous Compensation: ₹19.6 LPA fixed + ₹3.2 L ESOPs

Location: India

Education: Bachelor’s in Computer Science


Offers:

1. British Petroleum

		Role: Senior Software Developer
		Base: ₹28 LPA
		Joining Bonus: ₹3 L
		Variable Bonus: ₹2 L
		Total CTC: ₹33 LPA

2. Serrala

		Role: Senior Software Developer
		Base: ₹30 LPA
		Yearly Bonus: ₹3 L
		Other Bonus: ₹2 L
		Total CTC: ₹35 LPA

3. Chistats

		Role: Team Lead - Python
		Base: ₹40 LPA
		Bonus: ₹2 L
		Total CTC: ₹42 LPA

Observations:

	British Petroleum: Stable compensation but slightly lower CTC.
	Serrala: The best balance for base pay, bonuses, and company stability.
	Chistats: High CTC but involved working for a client in a smaller startup, which felt less secure.

Final Decision:

	Accepted Serrala due to its stability, positive culture, and growth potential.
